title: The Consequences of Not Creating a Jan. 6 Commission
sub_head: If Washington’s political system can’t come together, it may be showing it can’t reverse the dynamics that produced violence in the first place
body:
Arriving at the right answer often starts with asking the right question. That rule is worth pondering as the Senate this week considers whether to approve creation of a bipartisan commission to investigate the ransacking of the Capitol by an angry mob of Trump supporters on Jan. 6.
The main question that will be debated is: What will happen if such a panel is created?
The better question may be: What will happen if one isn’t?
For starters, there will be plenty of inquiries into the events of Jan. 6 anyway. Dozens of trials of those who entered the Capitol will unfold, producing a lot of new information and detail. Congressional committees, operating in a typically partisan fashion, will continue to call witnesses, hold public hearings and issue reports. Journalistic inquiries will continue.
But here’s one other consequence if Washington chooses to move down the road without such a commission: The political system will have shown that it remains incapable of reversing the very problems that produced the violence in the first place—severe partisanship, rampant mistrust of the other side, a new willingness to question election results.
